data.title: Support automatically hiding the menu bar
data.body:
Adds a `core.autoHideMenuBar` config setting to auto hide the menu bar on Linux and Windows. `Alt` will bring show the menu bar in this mode.

![auto-hide](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/671378/5079234/493f802c-6e67-11e4-9614-4ab547197e54.gif)

This new command `window:toggle-menu-bar` will also be available from the command palette and the `View` menu.

Closes #2914

data.title: Upgrading theme guides
data.body: Pulled the theme bits out of https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/4169

data.title: The program 'atom' received an X Window System error.
data.body:
Getting the following error with Atom 0.147.0-6708388

[14589:1117/124137:ERROR:browser_main_loop.cc(162)] Running without the SUID sandbox! See https://code.google.com/p/chromium/wiki/LinuxSUIDSandboxDevelopment for more information on developing with the sandbox on.
App load time: 138ms
ATTENTION: default value of option force_s3tc_enable overridden by environment.
[14620:1117/124137:INFO:renderer_main.cc(204)] Renderer process started
The program 'atom' received an X Window System error.
This probably reflects a bug in the program.
The error was 'BadValue (integer parameter out of range for operation)'.
  (Details: serial 274 error_code 2 request_code 12 minor_code 0)
  (Note to programmers: normally, X errors are reported asynchronously;
   that is, you will receive the error a while after causing it.
   To debug your program, run it with the --sync command line
   option to change this behavior. You can then get a meaningful
   backtrace from your debugger if you break on the gdk_x_error() function.)

Error happens when using the .deb and build from source.

OS: linux mint 17
windows manager: cinnamon

data.title: Improve user messaging
data.body:
Status: Implementation

The main goal here is to improve exception user experience (e.g. #3715). This can be extended to general user messaging. Say when the config file has an error, or info messages like when a theme has reloaded in dev-live-reload. 

In addition to showing the error message, the exception flow should either have
- A way to submit a bug report with the stack trace and related atom info
- A way to copy the entire stack trace
### Current state

A repo at https://github.com/atom/notifications results in growl-like messages:

![notifications](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/69169/5152024/6e5ef102-719c-11e4-851a-f28a0be91d72.gif)

data.title: Support middle mouse paste on Linux
data.body:
Adds for pasting the selection clipboard on middle mouse button on Linux.

Pastes on `mouseup` instead of `mousedown` which seemed to be consistent with of native inputs in Firefox and Chromium as well as Sublime on Ubuntu 14.04.

Copies all selection changes instead of just mouse driven selection changes so that things like `ctrl-D` and `ctrl-L` go to the selection clipboard.

Closes #2244
Closes #2272
Closes #3027

data.title: Syntax highlighting for Coffeescript isn't working correctly
data.body:
When using the following string:

```
  query = "INSERT INTO `#{testTable}` ( d_id, job_id, created_at, updated_at, first_name, last_name, phone, zip, start_time, duration, recording ) VALUES ( #{d.id}, #{job.id}, '#{escapeIt(body.start_time)}', '#{escapeIt(body.start_time)}', '#{escapeIt(body.first_name)}', '#{escapeIt(body.last_name)}', '#{escapeIt(body.caller_id)}', '#{escapeIt(d.zip)}', '#{escapeIt(body.start_time)}', #{escapeIt(body.call_duration)}, '#{escapeIt(recording)}' )"
```

and selecting Coffeescript for the syntax highlighting, it thinks I have an open string somewhere in that line.  When I go to the next line, my syntax highlighting is still showing green like there's a string I haven't closed.  JS2Coffee and Coffeescript.org both say the code is valid, which leads me to believe this is a bug.

data.title: Update linux.md
data.body: Update `git fetch` command to include the prune flag which will remove remote branches that no longer exist.

data.title: Strange Home button behavior when in middle of indentation
No cancel option for Search All Files
data.body:
Hi,
Thanks for great work.
Here is one question. Since there is no cancel option for the search all files. If it searches the project files and the project is large, it's not possible to stop that. What I do now is that just ignore the ongoing search but type in another word to search all. Not sure if there is any side effect of this operation. Therefore, suggest to have option to cancel the on going search.

Thanks and best regards.

data.title: Bug when after preview markdown or html
data.body:
OS: Windows 7 64-bit
Atom version: 0.146.0

Using Ctrl-Shift-M to preview markdown or html file, after close the preview, the area still on the editor area right side and keep blank.

data.title: Command editor:log-cursor-scope no longer cleanly logs the scopes
data.body: In older versions of Atom (before the `ScopeDescriptor` change by @benogle), the `editor:log-cursor-scope` command, activated by <kbd>Cmd+Alt+P</kbd> on OS X, would log an array of simple strings to the debug console like `['foo', 'bar', 'baz']`. Now it logs a `ScopeDescriptor` object which, while it can still be opened up to get the same information as always, requires a few mouse clicks to do so. It would be better if the command logged the `ScopeDescriptor.scopes` value instead.

data.title: Exclude VCS Ignored Paths Toggle Not Respected
data.body: If I switch off the Exclude VCS Ignored Paths option in my preferences, paths and files in my .gitignore file are still excluded from the tree view. I don't want that.

data.title: Separate instructions on packaging
data.body: Packaging has another user group / use case than building. People might want to build atom for themselves but not for others, so it is noisy to give them instructions on packaging, too. For that reason I think, the instructions on packaging should be extracted from the Building markdowns. There should be separate building instructions for the various platforms.

data.title: Consider bundling default font
data.body: wish u addon Noto fonts to editor and support laravel syntax hints and highlights

data.title: Reload causes cursor/selection misalignment (for @font-face fonts)
data.body:
Possibly related to #3201, if you have fonts loaded through `@font-face` (e.g. using my fonts package), a reload causes the cursor/selection alignment to misbehave. Switching to the default font (i.e. empty the font family box in settings) restores it. You can then switch back to an `@font-face` font and it will work properly again.

Steps to reproduce:
- Use an `@font-face` font as outlined here: https://discuss.atom.io/t/how-do-i-load-google-fonts-into-my-editors-styles/8321/7 (or by using http://atom.io/packages/fonts).
- Put the name of the font in settings (e.g. 'aka-coder').
- Open a file in Atom: all should look well in the new font.
- Choose View > Reload.
- Cursor and selection should now misalign. You can check this by double-click-selecting a word or by typing a row of characters.
- Switch to settings.
- Empty the font-family setting.
- Switch to the file and all should look well again in the default font.
- Switch to settings. 
- Put the name of the font in settings (e.g. 'aka-coder').
- Switch to the file and all should look well again in aka-coder.

data.title: Bug when starting editor under certain conditions
data.body:
When I closed the editor I had a file open in a tab. It was named "summarize". 
With the editor closed I ended up having to do some restructuring of the project folder and this file was moved into a directory called "summarize" under a different name.
Later in the day I tried to start up Atom again, it failed to the debug screen. It was throwing an error saying that this file was now a directory. I ended up having to rename the directory temporarily to be able to open the editor, then close the tab in the editor, rename the directory again to it's original name and all was well.
Suggestion: the editor should fail more gracefully in this circumstance. When a directory replaces a file of the same name, the editor should just close the tab or gray it out with an explanation or alert.

data.title: Undo reverts file and makes Redo impossible even without Vim Mode
data.body:
You'll probably say "oh no, not another undo issue report.."

But hey: I've lost enough work because of this and I tried anything I can find.

So here comes my rant.
- I'm using 0.146.0 binary distribution on Arch Linux
- I don't have Vim Mode ever installed
- I've read #2689 #2983 #3891 #3168 #3169
- I'm aware that <kbd>Ctrl</kbd><kbd>Alt</kbd><kbd>Z</kbd> is a trap.
- My <kbd>Ctrl</kbd><kbd>Z</kbd> is mapped to `core:undo`

Still losing data at random while undoing.

Here's the output of `apm list -i`

```
- atom-alignment (0.9.3)
- auto-detect-indentation (0.2.2)
- autocomplete-clang (0.3.1)
- autocomplete-plus (0.21.0)
- breeze-syntax (0.2.0)

- Zen (0.9.0)
```

Would love some assistance.
(_Trying `--safe` mode now_)

data.title: Upgrade to atom-shell@0.19.2
data.body:
Changelog:
- Add `plugins` attribute for `<webview>`
- Add `preload` attribute for `<webview>`
- Add `httpreferrer` attribute for `<webview>`
- Add `crashRepoter.getLastCrashReport` API
- Add `original-fs` module
- Add `preload` option for BrowserWindow
- Add APIs to toggle menu bar for BrowserWindow
- Fix wrong string when using `Buffer` for WebKits external string

**Linux**
- Use system window frame for undocked devtools

**Windows**
- Upload PDB files to symbol server
- Use native frame for `BrowserWindow` when DWM is off
- Fix setting default path for file dialogs

**Windows & Linux**
- Fix crash when showing error dialog on early initialization stage
- Make `auto-hide-menu-bar` work when number lock is on

data.body:
such as 
https://github.com/atom/atom/installer/xxx.exe
https://github.com/atom/atom/installer/xxx.deb

because s3.amazonaws.com is _blocked_ in china

data.title: Fix resetting scoped config defaults
data.body:
It would write an empty object for the parent key when there were no other objects in the parent key.

The settings view will call `atom.config.restoreDefault` for every option when viewing a language package. This fix will only save if the value changes, and will never set an empty object. 

Closes #4175

data.title: deactivating a deactivated package throws an exception
data.body:
Deactivating an already deactivated package throws an exception.  I can't show the error because I'm doing a `ctrl-alt-R` and the error just flashes.  I'm deactivating via `atom.packages.deactivatePackage('foo')` although I can imagine non-debug situations where this could happen.  In any case it's not good to throw in a harmless situation.
## Repro Steps
1. Deactive package with `atom.packages.deactivatePackage('foo')`
2. Do `ctrl-alt-R` and watch inspector to see red flash
## Versions
- **Atom:**       0.146.0
- **Atom-Shell:** 0.19.1
- **OS:**         Microsoft Windows 8.1 Pro with Media Center
- **Misc**
  - apm  0.111.0
  - npm  1.4.4
  - node 0.10.33
  - python 2.7.5
  - git 1.7.11.msysgit.1
  - visual studio 2013

---

<small>This report was created in and posted from the Atom editor using the package `bug-report` version 0.4.1.</small>

data.title: Add auto-indent when pasting
data.body:
Currently, auto-indent is not used when pasting. This makes sense for coffeescript and other indentation-sensitive languages, because in those languages, auto-indent would often make the indentation worse. This adds a separate config option, `autoIndentOnPaste` that allows auto-indentation to be used when pasting.

@atom/core Do you guys think there's anything we need to do make it clear that `autoIndentOnPaste` completely supercedes `normalizeIndentOnPaste`?

Closes #1407
- [x] auto-indent pasted text
- [x] in `::suggestedIndentForBufferRow`, base indentation on previous non-blank line
- [x] don't auto-indent when pasting after non-whitespace characters
- [x] make a separate config option, `editor.autoIndentOnPaste` for auto-indenting pasted text
- [x] add a description to the original `autoIndent` config option, differentiating it from `autoIndentOnPaste`

data.title: Upload Squirrel Windows assets to releases
data.body:
Publishes the Windows installer and nuget package files as part of the CI build.

Refs #3675

data.title: After copying with multiple selections, TextEditor::pasteText skips '{did,will}-insert-text' events
data.body:
`TextEditor::pasteText` calls `insertText` directly on selections when clipboard metadata contains multiple selections. This bypasses said events.

https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/text-editor.coffee#L2499

data.title: Option to auto-save changes when quitting app with new or changed documents
data.body: This is conditionalized in OS X by System Preferences | General: 'Ask to keep changes when closing documents' and 'Close windows when quitting an app' I think. But the feature should be available cross platform.

data.title: Clean up TextEditor::pasteText
data.body: Just some cleanup.

data.title: editor:will-be-removed appears in command palette
data.body:
Atom 0.146.0, when working on a project with a git repository, the command palette will contain the `editor:will-be-removed` event. If the project has no repo, it doesn't seem to appear.

![screen shot 2014-11-14 at 14 05 50](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1759837/5047896/73d2a7cc-6c11-11e4-9cc3-3c46d72983e9.png)

Steps to reproduce:

``` shell
$ git init
$ atom --safe .
```
- `cmd-n` to open a new editor.
- `cmd-shift-p` to open the palette and search for `will be removed`.

data.title: documentation improvement suggestion - how to see your changes to the source code without building
data.body:
I'm the one who asked a question in this link: https://discuss.atom.io/t/do-you-use-atom-while-hacking-on-the-core-editor/13207

All the answers were very valuable, but I think @postcasio's answer would be especially very helpful for newbies like me who just started contributing to Atom. I copied the answer to here for your convenience:

"-r sets the resources path, which is normally Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app. Your working copy is your local copy of the atom repository. So if you cloned to /Users/yjw9012/github/atom you would run:
atom -r /Users/yjw9012/github/atom
Then instead of loading the code bundled in Atom.app, it will load the code you're working on.
Also, looking at the source, dev mode will load from ~/github/atom it exists. So if you have your copy stored there, you can just run atom -d."

I was curious if there was a much faster way to see your code changes to the source code than rebuilding it by executing 'script/build'. It's true that building Atom takes a very few minutes (probably, less than 2 minutes), but I believe that some people might consider it's even too long.

My suggestion would be that we need to modify the answer above a little bit and put that in the build instruction for OS X(https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/docs/build-instructions/os-x.md) or other contribution guide pages at least.
